pasture land and cows: and looking across the beach is Mr, Garrett,
dealer in clems in an orange check waistcoat, tightfitting grey gaiters
and a plug hat as tall and stately as a belfry with zips in the sides .
as if to let the noise of the bells out* Mr. Garrett, dealer in clams,
is cleaning his morning8s stock brought from Rockaway Beach during
the night. He juicily squeezes his black plug of best Virginia between
Virginia black teeth, and sings to himself.
Clams, choice clams, here 8 s your Rockaway Beach clams fine sand

NARRs
So he sits end counts clams and counts gulls and counts sailing ships
going north and steamships going south, and anything else he can count
in the high hope of a hunch for one of Mr. Arnold8© lucky numbers*
GARR:
First prise of twenty thousand dollars: twelve thousand one hundred
and twenty prises, twenty two thousand blanks.
NAKR:
Ten years ago the Stats Legislature had forbidden the famous old'New
York lotteries$ but the proprietors are still finding loopholes to sat¬
isfy their customers who swarm through the bright May streets to produce
the busiest community that any man could desire to live in.
